Additionally, if DAC technologies are used, electr
icity and heat requirements to operate DAC could
The decreasing cost and increasing performance of renewable energy has generated interest in the
feasibility of providing nearly all energy services with renewables. Renewable energy includes wind
power, solar power, hydroelectric power, bioenergy, geother
mal energy, tidal power, and ocean power.
There are two primary frames around which 100% renewable energy systems are discussed: 100%
renewable electricity systems and 100% renewable energy systems, considering not only electricity but
It is technically feasible to use very high renewable shares (e.g., above 75% of annual regional
generation) to meet hourly electricity demand under a range of conditions, especially when VRE
options, notably wind and solar, are complemented
currently many grids with high renewable shares and large anticipated roles for VRE sources, in
particular wind and solar (see Section 6.4), in future low
large set of studies examines the feasibility of high renewable penetration and economic drivers under
different policy, technology, and market scenarios
(Denholm et al. 2021; Blanford et al. 2021; Bistline
et al. 2019; Hansen et al. 2019; Jenkins et al. 2018b; Cochran et al. 2014; Dowling et al. 2020; Deason
High wind and solar penetration involves techn
ical and economic challenges due to their unique
characteristics such as spatial and temporal variability, short
. These challenges become increasingly important as
There are many balancing options in systems with very high renewables
2021a; Mai et al. 2018; Milligan et al. 2015; Jen
Energy storage technologies like batteries, pumped hydro, and hydrogen can
provide a range of system services
ion batteries have received attention as costs fall and installations increase, but very high
renewable shares typically entail either dispatchable generation or
(Schill 2020; Arbabzadeh et al. 2019; Jenkins et al. 2018b)
technologies are part of a broad set of options (including synchronous condensers, demand
based technologies themselves) for providing grid services
To balance differences in resource availability, high renewable systems
will very likely entail investments in transmission capacity
Blechinger 2017; Macdonald et al. 2016; Mai and Et al 2014; Section 6.4.5)
. These increases will likely be accompa
expanded balancing regions to take advantage of geographical smoothing.
Dispatchable generation could include flexible fossil
carbon fuels such as hydrogen with lower minimum load levels
, renewables like hydropower, geothermal, or biomass
. The composition depends on costs and other
policy goals, though in all cases, capacity factors are low for these resources
load flexibility in the forms of energy efficiency, demand response, and demand flexibility, utilizing
